ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The readings of the class are comprehensive to all of Christian Mysticism. Eire does an amazing job in curating what texts we read in a way that makes sense in relation to each other but also highlights their uniqueness. The course is based off of the readings we do, so reading middle-aged text is really the only skill. Some analysis too.
A deeper understanding of mystics throughout the ages, a solid grasp on Christian history throughout the early and late middle ages.
learned a lot about Christian mysticism, its philosophies, famous figures, and famous works
Process of reviewing primary sources, tracking historical developments
I learned a lot about the Christian Mystical tradition. Professor Eires lectures were highly engaging, and discussion sections enriched my understanding of the readings.
I learned about Christian mystics, which included defining what a 'mystic' was. I learned how to read mystical texts and analyze what they were saying.

What mysticism is (a mystic in this context is essentially someone who has had an otherworldly religious experience), reading mystics' writings, learning about and interrogating mystics' theologies via discussion, how the history of Christianity influenced Christian mysticism
I learnt a lot about different forms of Christian mysticism, and was especially glad that I learned the wide variety of manifestations it took from 1200-1700
I learned how to manage a large reading load and parse out its most important details
learned more about medieval mystics and the lore around them
Analyzing medieval theological texts and grasping mystical concepts that defy regular language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Again, it's comprehensive course on Christian Mysticism. I left feeling like I knew everything I would need to know in that topic, and eager to make connections to the present. TF Amanda Griffin was incredible.
Weaknesses: I am not really sure this is a weakness, because I would agree that all the text that was assigned was relevant but I would say the readings are a bit over assigned. They are long and very dense, most weeks I came to section without having it all done. The TF seemed to know that, though. The lectures were not always engaging, but again I think that might be the fault of the topic being very dense and sometimes a bit boring.
This class is great, readings are really interesting and Professor Eire is an engaging lecturer.
Really organized and I wouldn't change a thing.
stellar discussion sections, lectures can be slightly drony sometimes

Strengths: interesting readings, thoughtful discussion
Weaknesses: n/a

Strengths - Carlos Eire is one of the best lecturers in the history department, foremost expert is the field of Protestant and Catholic religious studies, it is an interesting class 

Weakness - You learn of several random people, and not really of any broad historical thing.
Strengths: the course is incredibly well-taught and highly engaging, Amanda is a great TF, and the course material is super interesting; no weaknesses come to mind!
it was strong as Prof. Eire is a great lecturer, made lectures fun with his personal anecdotes and his experience with the topic
Its just excellent! Really, Eire is great
lectures started off really interesting but waned as the semester progressed
Great class overall!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would. Eire and the TFs he picks know their stuff. They are very committed to student learning and brilliant. Be prepared to do a lot of reading, and especially in Christian Mysticism, reading that can feel homogenous and specific. I felt like I learned a lot and would be very surprised if I did not find myself making connections to future courses.
I would definitely recommend this course, my favorite religion course I have taken.

YES ABSOLUTELY!!!!! This class is quite the gem. I went into it with some reservations but oh was I proven wrong. Professor Eire almost has a saint like quality to him which is almost fitting. He is incredibly knowledgeable and cares about his students. His lectures are riveting and I challenge anyone to remain unmoved after one of his lectures.
Yes! It's a great class for anyone looking to delve deeper into Christianity
Yes, if the student has a base level of interest in the class. I found it interesting because I already was interested in mysticism
I would definitely recommend this course or any course taught by Carlos Eire to another student. It is definitely an interesting class, and it is not an overwhelming workload either.
Yes! The course is really fun and interesting, and the subject matter is fascinating. You don't need to be Christian to enjoy this course; I'm an atheist, and I loved it!
For people interested in religious history or history more generally, definitely yes. If not, the nature of learning about ancient mystics might not appeal to everyone
Definitely! Too many people fail to understand mysticism. I, as a non-Christian non-mystic, still found it incredibly thought provoking (and, in many instances, persuasive).
Yes! If you have even an inkling of interest in Christian mysticism
Yes! You dont have a complete experience as a humanities student at Yale unless you take a course with Prof. Eire, and this class has the least requirement for background knowledge.
